story:
Filipinos are the largest Asian group in California and in 10 of the 13 Western States. They’re also the oldest Asian group in US history. Despite this, Filipino American history is absent in public K-12 education and especially in children’s books. 

                                             

Which is why I created Bridge + Delta Publishing, a Filipino American press focused on publishing stories where the Filipino American perspective is at the center of every story. As a children’s book author of Beautiful Eyes, a San Francisco Unified School District curriculum book, I saw there was a lack of publishers interested in the Filipino American experience. 

 

We make up such a large population in the West Coast. But if Filipino Americans are the largest population of Asian Americans on the West Coast, then why aren’t publishers paying attention to our stories? Instead of asking this question countless times, I decided to just open up shop and create the publishing house that’s paying attention to Filipino American history, art and culture.

One of the main goals of Bridge + Delta is to create a children’s book series that tells the stories of four Filipino American men and four Filipino American women who have changed US history. Our first book in the series is "Journey for Justice: The Life of Larry Itliong," by Dr. Dawn Mabalon, a Stanford trained historian, San Francisco State University history professor,  and National Scholar and member of the Board of Trustees of the Filipino American National Historical Society.

Illustrations are by Andre Sibayan, a California artist whose work has been front and center in promoting San Francisco Bay Area Filipino American cultural events, and who has created designs and art for Disney, Target, Quicksilver, the Gap and more.  

Part of our goal in publishing the first book in this series is to incorporate "Journey for Justice: The Life of Larry Itliong," into school district curriculum to be used in public education throughout the state of California.

If we are able to reach beyond our funding goal, we would love to begin production on our next children's book in the Filipino American history eight-book series. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $35,000 to help pay for production costs that goes into book publishing, like: 

  • Printing in the USA - these costs take up the bulk of any publishing budget
  • ISBN number and bar codes 
  • Additional design, illustration, editing
  • Meeting space (either online or physical, brick and mortar)
  • Research 
  • 5% of funds will also go to two nonprofits, Filipino American National Historical Society and the Little Manila Foundation. 

Purchase the different perks in our donation campaign as holiday gifts, baby shower gifts, birthday gifts, for your family members or for your school! We're proud of the books and merchandise we're offering as perks when you donate. All of which are quality educational products for children and their families and students and their schools! 

                        

The Impact

But why does a Filipino American history book series for children even matter? Because Filipino American History is American history. Because American history without Filipinos in it is an incomplete story. Because studies have shown that when children see themselves in their school books and history books, they do better academically. When children do better academically, doors open for them and they are able to gain skills to become our next generation of leaders: they will become our activists, lawyers, judges, policy makers, legislators, peace keepers, teachers, researchers, and our artists. When caregivers and communities are able to read these stories to Filipino American students, and families can read these books together, we are all reminded that we can accomplish great things together and as individuals. The next generation need to see themselves in a telling of American history in which Filipino Americans are acknowledged for their contributions to this country. This book series is one step closer to a richer, vibrant, relevant, and more accurate history of the United States.

So yes, this matters for the Filipino American community and this matters to children and their families. Ultimately, this matters on personal, local, state and national levels.

Risks & Challenges

Printing costs are similar to the stock market. Depending on paper costs, printing pricing goes up or down. We could run into printing costs that are beyond what our funding campaign raised. We can address that by printing a smaller amount of books or print less pages.

It also takes some time to work with academics, editors, writers, graphic designers and illustrators. But we're on track to complete Journey for Justice at the end of December, with copies and perks mailed out in January 2018. 

We will update all of you throughout the process through Bridge + Delta Publishing news page, Instagram, Facebook page, and Indiegogo page.

Our team is experienced in production and publications. While there are always some hiccups in production, we have knowledgeable leadership, and a deadline driven team. A little bit about our team:

Publisher/Editor: Gayle Romasanta is a published author and writer, with a publication history that spans over 20 years. She has written for one of the largest media/news companies in the United States, the McClatchy Company, and has been a founding editor for numerous magazines and literary journals. Her work has been published in newspapers, magazines, anthologies, as a children's book, commercials and for the stage. She is also the founder of the Filipino American sorority, Kappa Psi Epsilon, with chapters at University of California, Davis, Los Angeles, California State University Long Beach, Sacramento and San Francisco State University.

Writer/Researcher/History Series Curator: Dr. Dawn Mabalon, the curator of this history series, is a third generation Filipina born and raised in Stockton, California, the daughter and granddaughter of farmworkers and teachers, and an associate professor of history at San Francisco State University. She’s also the author of books, articles, essays and poetry about the Filipino American experience. Her books include Little Manila is in the Heart: The Making of the Filipina/o American Community in Stockton, California, Filipinos In Stockton, and she was a co-editor of Filipinos in San Francisco. She serves as a National Scholar and Trustee of the Filipino American National Historical Society and is the co-founder of the Little Manila Foundation in Stockton, California. She received an M.A. in Asian American Studies from UCLA and a PhD in American history from Stanford University.

Illustrator/Graphic Design: Andre Sibayan is a seasoned illustrator and graphic designer. He has created and designed artwork for Savor Filipino, Undiscovered SF, a creative night market in SOMA Pilipinas, San Francisco, San Francisco State University, the Gap, Disney, Quicksilver, Target, Wal-mart and other name brands. His work in the San Francisco Bay Area Filipino community has spanned over 20 years. If your child is wearing a cool t-shirt from Target, chances are, Andre designed it.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate, please share our video and our Indiegogo page!  Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us get to our goal! We’ll keep you all posted on how well we’re doing and how the books are doing in production. We have faith in our community! We know you  want to invest in this project to get this Filipino American history series published and onto the bookshelves of our friends, families, neighbors, and into public school classrooms as part of the curriculum!

But we're on track to complete Journey for Justice at the end of December, with copies and perks mailed out in January 2018. We will update all of you throughout the process through Bridge + Delta Publishing news page, Instagram, Facebook page, and Indiegogo page.Our team is experienced in production and publications. While there are always some hiccups in production, we have knowledgeable leadership, and a deadline driven team. A little bit about our team:Publisher/Editor: Gayle Romasanta is a published author and writer, with a publication history that spans over 20 years. She has written for one of the largest media/news companies in the United States, the McClatchy Company, and has been a founding editor for numerous magazines and literary journals. Her work has been published in newspapers, magazines, anthologies, as a children's book, commercials and for the stage. She is also the founder of the Filipino American sorority, Kappa Psi Epsilon, with chapters at University of California, Davis, Los Angeles, California State University Long Beach, Sacramento and San Francisco State University.Writer/Researcher/History Series Curator: Dr. Dawn Mabalon, the curator of this history series, is a third generation Filipina born and raised in Stockton, California, the daughter and granddaughter of farmworkers and teachers, and an associate professor of history at San Francisco State University. She’s also the author of books, articles, essays and poetry about the Filipino American experience. Her books include Little Manila is in the Heart: The Making of the Filipina/o American Community in Stockton, California, Filipinos In Stockton, and she was a co-editor of Filipinos in San Francisco. She serves as a National Scholar and Trustee of the Filipino American National Historical Society and is the co-founder of the Little Manila Foundation in Stockton, California. She received an M.A. in Asian American Studies from UCLA and a PhD in American history from Stanford University.Illustrator/Graphic Design: Andre Sibayan is a seasoned illustrator and graphic designer. He has created and designed artwork for Savor Filipino, Undiscovered SF, a creative night market in SOMA Pilipinas, San Francisco, San Francisco State University, the Gap, Disney, Quicksilver, Target, Wal-mart and other name brands. His work in the San Francisco Bay Area Filipino community has spanned over 20 years. If your child is wearing a cool t-shirt from Target, chances are, Andre designed it. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can’t donate, please share our video and our Indiegogo page!  Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us get to our goal! We’ll keep you all posted on how well we’re doing and how the books are doing in production. We have faith in our community! We know you  want to invest in this project to get this Filipino American history series published and onto the bookshelves of our friends, families, neighbors, and into public school classrooms as part of the curriculum!

story:
If you're here, you probably already know what this is.

Yes, this is the Background Pony print. There are many people that have already expressed interest in it, and I am ready to provide it. As gathering funds has become somewhat of a challenge, I am opening a campaign where you can fund the printing yourself.

The end goal is the minimum for the print to go through, as it has been negotiated with the publisher. You can contribute after it is met, no problem.

Short Summary

The book will be cloth-bound, with cover elements embossed on it in silver. It is split in two tomes of 550 pages each, set on 60x90 1/16 (220x150 mm) 80g paper. Due to high cost of color printing required by the story, a B&W version will also be available, with colored elements replaced by analogous typeset representations. 

What We Need & What You Get

By contributing according the perks on the right, you'll get the book you want to get. Everything is already included: shipping, handling, and extra care.

Risks & Challenges

I live in Russia. We love books here, and that's why I've started this in first place. But, as Russia is currently not at best terms with the rest of the world, a lot of organization-related things have been very hard to make right. Right now, I hope that we'll be able to make it. Don't worry, there are no issues with shipping.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want the book yourself, maybe you know someone else who does! I have been constrained in my book count before, and now I've resolved the issue. You can sign up for the book, even if you didn't before.

And that's all there is to it.

 

(Confused? Learn about the community at https://whatisabrony.com/)

story:
My name is Lionel Touzellier. I am 35 years old and I’m living in France.

I’m passionate about JFK’s assassination as it made history of USA and I’m studying this event for five years now.

You may find it hard to believe but during my researches I have discovered a NEW LEAD PREVIOUSLY UNSEEN regarding this assassination. Indeed, despite billions of written pages on this topic and thousands of video footages, my idea was never raised before.

While going into it in depth I realized that it was really making sense and I have decided to write a book to set out this new lead.

I have spent two years writing this book and now I’m very proud to have finished it. It is self-published on amazon.fr website. You will find the link below :

http://www.amazon.fr/Assassinat-JFK-Invisible-Lionel-Touzellier-ebook/dp/B00J0L7PMG/ref=zg_bs_895004031_7

[Note: From my point of view, the theory exposed in this work definitely solves the JFK mystery !!!]

So you’ll probably ask : what is my project ? Very simple : I would REALLY like to translate my book (currently in French) in English so that all American citizens could take note of my theory.

To achieve this I need 5 000$. Indeed translators usually charge about 10 dollars per page (It is the best price scale I found), My book contains about 500 pages.

Regarding my personal finances it is too much. As a self-published author I cannot afford this translation. This is why I’m appealing to your generosity.

It is important to underline that there is ABSOLUTELY NO RISK. If i succeed to collect this sum of money, my book will be automatically translated and then straight published ( ebook and paper book). There will be no additional cost to do this.

Please help me to translate this book.

For me.

For American people.

To honor the memory of United States of America…

story:
My Story

Hi, my name is Dwier Brown and I had the amazing fortune to be in one of the best baseball movies of all time, Field of Dreams, a movie that impacted my life in ways I never could have imagined.  Over the years, I’ve had countless strangers come up to me and tell me the profound way that film has changed their lives and their relationships with their fathers. I started to write these stories down, not just the stories from these strangers, but the stories from the film set, the stories of the changing relationship with my own father, the stories of amazing coincidences, that just like the movie, were so full of magic, I almost couldn’t believe they were real.

I always thought, someday, I’ll write a book.

Well that day is here and as I’ve been working on my final edits, I realized, my dream was not just to write a book, my dream is to connect with all of you through this book. As James Earl Jones’ character says in Field of Dreams “America has rolled by like an army of stream rollers. It has been erased like a blackboard, rebuilt and erased again. But baseball has marked the time. This field, this game: it’s a part of our past. It reminds us of all that once was good and could be again.”

My dream is to meet all of you at baseball parks across America and for an afternoon we could all put away our laptops and cell phones and enjoy the simple pleasure of meeting face to face, of telling each other stories of little league and backyard games of catch, of our fathers, of baseball.

Here is where I need your help. In order to do an old fashioned RV book tour like this, where I’m not hustled from one appointment to another, but can take the time to truly connect and go to your hometowns and baseball fields, I need to be independently funded.  Some people have told me this is impossible but I believe that together, we humans are capable of just about anything. Or more appropriately put I believe in the philosophy “If you build it …”


Here are some specifics on what I need to complete this book and hit the road:


The minimum goal is $13,000 and here's why:

* RV Rental: $1,600 (for two week rental. But the more money raised, the longer         I can stay on the road). 

* Gasoline: $1,400

* Camp Sites: $600 (for two weeks)

* Final Edits For The Book: $3,200

* Book Design: $1,200

* Publishing: $5,000


  The Perks

The main idea behind starting this campaign, was that I would pre-sell the book in order to fund the book tour and finish the book itself. I created the $25 perk of an autographed copy of "If You Build It..." as the bread and butter to hopefully get me out the door.  If you're feeling generous or excited about the tour, I've got some really fun perks for our larger contributors, like my flying out to have dinner and "a catch" with you and your friends! Check out all of our perks below...


If I Am Unable To Raise All The Funds

If my funding goal is not reached, the contributions I do raise, will go to the publishing of the book and possibly funding a less ambitious book tour.


            Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to buy a book or make a contribution? No problem! You can help in so many other ways! I welcome your contribution just getting the message out there!

* Share this video campaign on your Facebook Page

* Share with your email list

* Use Indiegogo's share tools

story:
Dislaimer: I'm not good at videos :-)

Short Summary

I'm a software developer working solely on F/OSS software and Linux since 1997, a proud member of Debian community since 1999 (originally a debian-powerpc porter and now one of the armhf porters), a non-mainstream architectures advocate (personal favourites PowerPC and now ARM), a software optimization freak and an SIMD/algorithm vectorization fanatic. More details on my site http://freevec.org.

During the past years, I've had to work on porting algorithms for several SIMD engines, including PowerPC Altivec/VMX in the beginning (some Cell SPU inbetween), and lately ARM NEON and Intel SSE* (and their variations). While I had to work on one architecture only, things were easy, however afterwards I had to constantly use Google or several reference manuals to find out that bit of extra information about this particular instruction on eg. SSSE4.*. And I found myself constantly searching on Amazon and elsewhere, for a comparative book or even online reference about all/most SIMD engines. For a simple example, how to do a vector unpacking/shuffling in those 3 major SIMD engines? Is there more than one way on each platform? And what are the benefits of each method? Which is the most performant? Which utilizes the SIMD engine better and leaves no bubbles in the pipeline? Etcetera, etcetera.

So, after a lot of search and eventual frustration, I've decided to give it a shot myself. I plan to write one or two books on all 3 major SIMD engines:

  • The first will be a plain reference, with comparisons and showing equivalent instructions on each engine, on both assembly and C intrinsics.

  • The second book will be more like a cookbook, covering simple and complex algorithms -some of which can be found online already, some not- again for all 3 SIMD engines.

Whether I write one or two books will depend on the funding I receive. If it covers just the requested funding, then I'll write a reference book with some clever tricks/recipes included for several algorithms and stuff like optimizations, pipelines and comparisons between the internals of each SIMD engine. If funding surpasses my expectations, I'll definitely write a second book and give it the attention it deserves, covering more algorithms and more advanced topics (like autovectorization perhaps). But you will definitely get at least one book.

Why you should fund this?

Well, if, like me, you've had to walk around the complete maze that is SIMD engine implementations and want to port your algorithm to one or more of those architectures without spending half your day on Google and hard to reach sites, then you might want to help this effort. I know I would definitely help if something like that was available 3-4 years ago. Right now, I'm just at the point that I don't want to wait any longer and I want to "Just Do It!".

I expect this to take approximately 3-4 months to complete, perhaps less if I really push it, but I prefer to do this properly rather than hastily. I will definitely complete it regardless of the funds received as I want it for myself anyway. But a successful campaign would help me finish it sooner rather than later, as I wouldn't have to worry about real life expenses and I could devote myself to this.

What will you get back?

Besides my eternal gratitude? Depending on the amount, you'll either get your name in the credits, a free t-shirt, an e-book or also a printed book or a conference call explaining the book -any parts you would like.

story:
Overview

This year marks the start of the Polytheist Leadership Conference – and 2014 is the fourth and most community-focused year in the Otherfaith! We're a modern polytheistic religion seeking to get more involved in our connected communities, and Aine Llewellyn heads the faith.

We hope to raise enough money in this campaign to send Aine to this conference, where a variety of polytheists will be meeting, all with the goal of growing polytheism. Since the Otherfaith is polytheistic, this opportunity would be amazing if we can achieve it.

  • Aine Llewellyn is the founder and current head of the Otherfaith. She has been a Pagan and polytheist for nine years, and she founded the Otherfaith with the intent of creating a flourishing communal religion.

  • The chance to speak at the conference as a presenter offers more publicity to the faith, important during these formative years. It also allows the faith to be, rightfully, influenced by the other polytheistic religions growing around it! This chance could mean huge things for the 'faith!

What We Need

The money you contribute will be spent toward:

  • $500 toward plane ticket (round trip)
  • $300 hotel expenses
  • $100 other travel expenses 
  • $50 religious paraphernalia (artwork, information packets)
  • $50 emergency funds 

What You Get

By contributing to this campaign, the Other People contribute to their voices being heard, and the Otherfaith is further established as a growing, emerging religion! We offer a variety of perks for contributors as well.

  • Those who contribute between $10-25 will receive a Tarot reading from Aine Llewellyn, through email or Skype (whichever they prefer).
  • Those who contribute between $50-100 will receive a charm or charm pack (small cards with sacred symbols on them), as well as a Tarot reading.
  • Those who contribute between $100-500 will receive a blog highlight & thank you on both the Patheos blog, the Tumblog, & the Wordpress blog. They will also receive a charm pack & Tarot reading.

The Impact

The Polytheist Leadership Conference is all about getting polytheists together to talk, face to face. So far, the Otherfaith has been online - born and cultivated - and the chance to talk face-to-face with other polytheists is invaluable. It also gives the Otherfaith space as an emerging polytheist religion, and that, too, is a priceless opportunity.

  • As a new/emerging religion with new gods, the Otherfaith can offer new perspectives and ideas concerning polytheism in our modern world, as well as bring innovative ideas to the table.
  • We cannot undervalue the chance at community building that comes from offline interaction. Networking, building friendships, and understanding people better is a great thing, and the conference will allow that to happen. We need to recover from last year's vitriol, and one way to do that is to put forth a hand.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but you would like to help, you can!

  • Spread this campaign on Facebook, Tumblr, and Twitter! The more people who see it, the more contributors are possible. There are a variety of tools and buttons on Indiegogo that you can use to share this campaign!
  • Talking about and sharing information about the Otherfaith also helps us, immensely. That is how many possible and current devotees come to learn about us, and hearing about us from friends helps people feel comfortable. So, please, share who we are and what we do!

What Happens if We Don't Meet Our Goal

If we don't meet our goal of $1000, the funds received (since this is a flexible funding campaign) will go to attending next year's (2015) Pantheacon, in San Jose, California.

story:
Jo's Poetry Excerpts from My Resume"
Hi you don't know me yet but I'm a poet. I've always been a poet but up until a year ago I was an unpublished poet. You see I signed a publishing contract with Tate publishing and I realized that I didn't have a clue about the business. So decided to start a facebook page called Jo's Poetry Excerpts from My resume. I started out with a video blog of me tracking my journey as I wrote my next book. It was pretty rough. But aren't first ventures all that way. Learn as you go for the novice. Well that's me. I also posted poetry and journal entries from my writing. I chronicled my process and every question I thought was pertinent to self publishing. I blogged just every step I took and i shared insights to my own self as I grew and learned.
I talked about writing of course. But also the very beginnings, like what's my title going to be and what's the subject matter. There's a video on inspiration, encouragement, marketing, a few a those, daily insights, legal stuff like, copyrights and getting grants to publish. That was a bust. All the way up to formatting and what not to do and don't do that again. As well as videoing some early phases of spoken word. It got better. trust me.
so now I'm once again at printing. Because it takes money and while I've been very creative at putting myself out there and building an audience and selling my work piece by piece. It gets expensive. And when you're just starting out in the industry you don't get paid much. So every time I thought I had a little money saved I realized I need so much more.
So this project is to help me raise the money I need to print "Jo's Poetry Excerpts from My Resume" the book.
I decided that i will need about 400 to 500 books to start. That's going to cost about $1,600. Now this will include the cost of the actual printing and the cover of the book.
If I don't reach my goal then what ever money I do receive will go to the printing only of as many books as possible. I will go with a generic cover with just the words on it.
My project is in my opinion a good source to all those who want a step by step instructions to the process of writing. "Excerpts from My Resume" is a sister to "My Resume". It's written from my perspective as a mother, wife, sister, friend, employee, lover, enemy and human being.
I come from a family of 14 siblings and we lived on the south side of Chicago, to the suburbs of Illinois. Life was challenging as a young black girl from a large family in a poor neighborhood. My poetry talks about how I overcame and became the person I am today.
My biggest challenge to date in this project is getting the funding I need to print my book. I have looked into grants and there really are not any for self publishing and loans are just out of the question. This I blogged in my videos.
So I need your help to me complete my project and continue to share what I have learned and know with the public.
Contribute  to Jo's Poetry "Excerpts from My Resume", join the journey, enjoy and share it with someone.
story_txt: Jo's Poetry Excerpts from My Resume"Hi you don't know me yet but I'm a poet. I've always been a poet but up until a year ago I was an unpublished poet. You see I signed a publishing contract with Tate publishing and I realized that I didn't have a clue about the business. So decided to start a facebook page called Jo's Poetry Excerpts from My resume. I started out with a video blog of me tracking my journey as I wrote my next book. It was pretty rough. But aren't first ventures all that way. Learn as you go for the novice. Well that's me. I also posted poetry and journal entries from my writing. I chronicled my process and every question I thought was pertinent to self publishing. I blogged just every step I took and i shared insights to my own self as I grew and learned. I talked about writing of course. But also the very beginnings, like what's my title going to be and what's the subject matter. There's a video on inspiration, encouragement, marketing, a few a those, daily insights, legal stuff like, copyrights and getting grants to publish. That was a bust. All the way up to formatting and what not to do and don't do that again. As well as videoing some early phases of spoken word. It got better. trust me. so now I'm once again at printing. Because it takes money and while I've been very creative at putting myself out there and building an audience and selling my work piece by piece. It gets expensive. And when you're just starting out in the industry you don't get paid much. So every time I thought I had a little money saved I realized I need so much more.So this project is to help me raise the money I need to print "Jo's Poetry Excerpts from My Resume" the book.I decided that i will need about 400 to 500 books to start. story:
Last year, the UK’s three largest literary festivals featured over 2000 authors.

Of those 2000+ authors, only 4% were from Black Caribbean, Black African, South Asian or East Asian backgrounds.

We’re aiming to change that.

February 2016 sees the debut of Bare Lit: a literary festival focused entirely on writers of colour.

Unlike other literary festivals which often confine non-white authors to one-off 'diversity' panels, Bare Lit Festival gives authors of colour the platform and visibility they deserve. 

We want to counteract the trend of equating literary merit with whiteness by highlighting the amazing variety of work currently being produced by BAME writers. That’s why we’ve put together an exciting programme of performances, panels and conversations -- such as ‘Second-Generation Poets in Exile’, ‘What Does Liberation in Literature Look Like?', (Re)writing Pasts and Futures' and much more. Find further information about the program on our events page here.

This we hope will be the first year of many.

But to make this happen, we need your help.

To cover the costs of paying guests, booking venues, promotion and festival administration, we need to raise £7000.

This will help us to provide a high-quality festival experience for attendees and affirm the importance of valuing writers of colour, both in the UK literary scene and as a whole.

In the perks section you'll see we're offering the "Complict No More" e-book:

“Complicit No More” is a collection of essays curated by Yasmin Gunaratnam. It tackles the crosscutting facets of complicity as they play out within our relationships to our bodies, each other, our communities, to media representations and to mobilisation.

 

Limited edition Media Diversified tote bags:

...and festival tickets. As well as giving your support, we hope you can join us for what promises to be a groundbreaking cultural event!


On Friday 26th February join us for our opening night launch party at the award winning Betsey Trotwood pub which will include live music from Peter Brathwaite, a poetry performance by Khairani Barokka and a DJ set by AKA Mama Junk. (Further Info)

On Saturday we have a full day of events at both the Betsey Trotwood and the Free Word Centre in Farringdon, London and on Sunday a full day of events at the Betsey Trotwood. We will be hosting a terrific line up of writers across a variety of genres -- including fiction, poetry, politics and sci-fi/fantasy -- with celebrated writers such as Leila Aboulela, Jane Yeh, Selina Nwulu, Zen Cho and more.

Tickets will also be available from the Free Word Centre.

Find us on twitter @BareLit

Website: www.barelitfestival.com


In 2015, we hosted a Literatures of Colour panel at the Stoke Newington Festival chaired by Chimene Suleyman and with panelists Sunny Singh, Courttia Newland, Kavita Bhanot (editor of ‘Too Asian, Not Asian Enough’), and Bidisha, discussing the experiences of writers of colour.


Bare Lit Festival is organised by the team behind Media Diversified, a young and growing non-profit organisation which seeks to cultivate and promote skilled writers of colour. Live since July 2013, the initiative is already diversifying the UK’s media landscape, providing important, challenging and new content which contributes to global as well as domestic discussion on issues of social justice, equality, gender, politics, economics and pop culture. In March 2015 Media Diversified launched its Experts Directory, a searchable resource for media organisations of all sizes to subscribe to.


OUR GUESTS

Below are some of the authors featured in the international line-up for Bare Lit Festival 2016.

We'll be adding more info in campaign updates as the festival approaches.

Xiaolu Guo is a novelist, essayist, screenwriter and film maker. She was born in south-eastern China in 1973 and studied Film at Beijiing Film Academy and the UK National Film & TV School.

Her novel in English translation, Village of Stone (2004), was shortlisted for the 2005 Independent Foreign Fiction Prize and the 2006 International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award. It was followed by her first novel written in English, A Concise Chinese-English Dictionary for Lovers (2007), which tells the story of Z, a Chinese student‘s encounters in London and her inner journey of self-discovery. It was shortlisted for the 2007 Orange Prize for Fiction.

In April 2013, she was named one of the 'Best of Young British Novelists' by Granta Magazine.

Khairani Barokka is an Indonesian writer, poet, artist, and disability and arts (self-)advocate in London. Among her honors, she was an NYU Tisch Departmental Fellow for her Masters, Emerging Writers Festival’s (AUS) Inaugural International Writer-In-Residence, and Indonesia’s first Writer-In-Residence at Vermont Studio Center. Okka is the writer/performer/producer of, among others, a deaf-accessible, solo spoken word/art show, “Eve and Mary Are Having Coffee”. It premiered at Edinburgh Fringe 2014 as Indonesia’s only representative, with a grant from HIVOS. She was recognized in 2014 by UNFPA as one of Indonesia’s “Inspirational Young Leaders Driving Social Change” for “raising awareness of disability through inclusive arts”, and has been awarded six residencies, with a seventh upcoming. Published internationally in anthologies and journals, Okka has presented work extensively, in nine countries, is co-editor of forthcoming "HEAT", an anthology of Southeast Asian urban writing (Buku Fixi Publishing, 2016), the author of forthcoming poetry-art book "Indigenous Species" (Tilted Axis Press, 2016), and a PhD-by-practice candidate at Goldsmiths, as an LPDP Scholar. 

Dean Atta is a poet and educator, with a BA Philosophy and English from the University of Sussex and an MA Writer/Teacher from Goldsmiths College, University of London. He is a member of Keats House Poets Forum and Malika’s Poetry Kitchen. He is also an Associate Artists with Mouthy Poets and New Writing South. He has been commissioned to write poems for Keats House Museum, National Portrait Gallery, Tate Britain and Tate Modern. His debut poetry collection I Am Nobody's Nigger was published in 2013 by The Westbourne Press. He lives in London and works internationally. 

Malika Booker is a writer, spoken word and multidisciplinary artist. She has appeared world-wide both independently and with the British Council. She was one of the touring poets with Bittersweet in 1999/2000 and since has featured in the spoken word project, Modern Love, and in Kin at the Barbican in 2004 . Her book, Breadfruit, was published in 2007.

She was commissioned to co-produce a poetry film to commemorate the Royal Festival Hall's 50th Birthday Celebrations in Spring 2001. Her first musical play, Catwalk, commissioned by NITRO, ran at the Tricycle Theatre in June 2001 and had a successful UK tour.

Malika Booker also jointly runs 'Malika's Kitchen', a writers' collective based in London and Chicago. Her latest play, Unplanned, opened in Spring 2007, with a run at Battersea Arts Centre. Her book, Breadfruit, was also published in 2007. Her latest poetry collection is Pepper Seed, published by Peepal Tree Press in 2013.


Zen Cho was born and raised in Malaysia. She is the author of Crawford Award-winning short story collection Spirits Abroad, and editor of anthology Cyberpunk: Malaysia, both published by Buku Fixi. She has also been nominated for the Campbell Award for Best New Writer and the Pushcart Prize, and honour-listed for the Carl Brandon Society Awards, for her short fiction. Her debut novel, Sorcerer to the Crown, is the first in a historical fantasy trilogy published by Ace/Roc Books (US) and Pan Macmillan (UK). She lives in London with her partner and practises law in her copious free time.

Sunny Singh, was born in Varanasi, India, and brought up in various Indian cantonment towns, Islamabad, Pakistan and New York City, USA. She studied at Brandeis University (USA), Jawaharlal Nehru University (India), and University of Barcelona (Spain).

Her debut novel, Nani’s Book Of Suicides, published in 2000, was described as a “first novel of rare scope and power.” The Spanish translation of the novel won the inaugural Mar de Letras prize in 2003. Her second book, a work of non-fiction titled Single In The City: The Independent Woman’s Handbook (2001), was a first-of-its-kind exploration of single women in contemporary India and described as “witty and insightful.” Her second novel, With Krishna’s Eyes (2006), has been commended for its “profound insight” and described as “memorable”. Her latest novel, Hotel Arcadia, is published by Quartet Books and available from bookshops and e-retailers across UK. Her short stories have been published by prestigious international literary journals including The Drawbridge and World Literature Today.

Her creative nonfiction and academic writing has been published across the world in key journals and anthologies. She also writes for newspapers and magazines, in Spanish and English, across the globe.



Tendai Huchu’s first novel, The Hairdresser of Harare, was released in 2010 to critical acclaim, and has been translated into German, French, Italian and Spanish. His short fiction in multiple genres and nonfiction have appeared in The Manchester Review, Ellery Queen’s Mystery Magazine, Gutter, Interzone, AfroSF, Wasafiri, Warscapes, The Africa Report and elsewhere. In 2013 he received a Hawthornden Fellowship and a Sacatar Fellowship. He was shortlisted for the 2014 Caine Prize. His new novel is The Maestro, The Magistrate & The Mathematician.

Leila Aboulela is a Sudanese-born writer whose work, written in English, has received critical acclaim and a high profile for its distinctive exploration of identity, migration and Islamic spirituality. Highlighting the challenges facing Muslims in Europe and “telling the stories of flawed complex characters who struggle to make choices using Muslim logic”, Aboulela’s work explores significant political issues. Her personal faith and the move in her mid-twenties from Sudan to Scotland are a major influence on her work. Literary influences include Arab authors Tayeb Salih and Naguib Mahfouz as well as Ahdaf Soueif, Jean Rhys, Anita Desai and Doris Lessing. The Scottish literary landscape and writers such as Alan Spence and Robin Jenkins have also been influential. Leila Aboulela’s works have been included in cultural educational programs supported by the British Council and the National Endowment for the Humanities in the US.

Robin Yassin-Kassab is the author of the novel The Road from Damascus.

He has lived and worked in London, France, Pakistan, Turkey, Syria, Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Oman and now lives in Scotland.

He is co-author with Leila al-Shami of the forthcoming book on the Syrian revolution and war, Burning Country. He has lived and worked in London, France, Pakistan, Turkey, Syria, Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Oman and now lives in Scotland.

His journalism on Syria has appeared at the Guardian, the National, al-Jazeera, Foreign Policy and elsewhere.

He is a co-editor and regular contributor to PULSE, recently listed by Le Monde Diplomatique as one of its five favourite websites.


Selina Nwulu is a writer, poet and researcher for a think tank.

She has written for a number of outlets such as The Guardian, Red Pepper, the Free Word Centre and Sable litmag.

Her work has been published in a variety of magazines and anthologies including collections by the RSA, Lunar Poetry, and Emma Press. She has performed at a number of festivals including Glastonbury, Edinburgh Fringe and Fiery Tongues Festival in Holland. She has previously toured nationally with Apples and Snakes, representing London as part of the ‘Public Address II tour’

Her work often touches on social and environmental justice as well as identity, nostalgia and belonging. 

Her first chapbook collection, The Secrets I Let Slip, published by Burning Eye Books is out now. She is currently Young Poet Laureate for London 2015/6.


Jane Yeh is an American poet who has lived in England for over a decade. Born in New Jersey, she was educated at Harvard University, the University of Iowa—where she took an MFA at the prestigious writers’ program—and at Manchester Metropolitan University. She has taught at a number of universities in the UK, including Oxford Brookes University, and is now a Senior Researcher in Creative Writing at Kingston University.

She has published two collections with Carcanet: Marabou (2005), which was nominated for the Forward Prize for Best First Collection, the Whitbread Book Award and the Jerwood Aldeburgh First Collection Prize, and The Ninjas (2012). She has received many other awards and fellowships for her work, including a New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowship, an Academy of American Poets Prize, and a residency at Yaddo, and was a judge for the 2013 National Poetry Competition. She has also written on a number of subjects, from fashion to sport, for publications including The Village Voice and The Times Literary Supplement.


London born author and speaker Tosin Coker is proclaimed as the UK’s first black sci-fi author.  Within less than three months of her powerful début 'The Mouth of Babes' hitting the bookshelves, Tosin had attracted the attention of esteemed producer and director, Menelik Shabazz.

Calling upon her own life experiences as an inheritor of the Sickle Cell blood disorder, Tosin inspires by way of example, enthusing that "the only limitations are those set by the boundaries of the mind".

Haris Durrani is a writer of fiction, memoir, and academic essays. His debut, Technologies of the Self, received the Driftless Novella Prize and is forthcoming from Brain Mill Press.  He is an M.Phil. candidate in History and Philosophy of Science at University of Cambridge and holds a B.S. in Applied Physics from Columbia University, where he co-founded The Muslim Protagonist Symposium.


Anthony Anaxagorou is an award winning poet, prose writer, playwright, performer and educator. Since becoming the first young poet to win the London Mayor’s Poetry Slam in 2002, he has continued to be an inspiring and important voice in spoken word, publishing eight volumes of poetry, a spoken word EP and a book of short stories. His collection ‘The Blink That Killed The Eye’ was published by Jacaranda Books in 2014 and he has since won the Groucho Maverick Award in 2015 consisting of a £10,000 prize, a lifetime membership to the club and a Gavin Turk sculpture. Anthony is also the founder and artistic director of Out-Spoken, an incredible event of poetry and live music in London, and he is the chief editor and founder of Out-Spoken Press.

Anthony has performed alongside artists such as Kate Tempest, Akala and Linton Kwesi Johnson, as well as making numerous appearances on BBC, and in 2013 his poem ‘Dialectics’ was interpreted and performed by Cirque du Soleil in Las Vegas. Poems such as ‘I Am Not A Poet’, ‘If I Told You’ and ‘You’ have achieved wide acclaim for their honest and articulate interpretation of the truths of the world, delivering powerful messages illustrated with wondrous imagery to create a variety of meanings in a single line and a wealth of responses and reactions to his emotion-evoking and awe-inspiring words. 


Bwesigye Bwa Mwesigire is the co-founder of the Writivism pan-African literary initiative. He has written about literature, arts, culture and politics for a range of publications including The Guardian, This is Africa and Chimurenga. He has appeared at a range of literary events including Africa Writes, Storymoja, Ake and International Literature Showcase and is currently an MSc Fellow at the African Leadership Centre (ALC), King's College London. He has previously taught Law and Human Rights at Makerere, Uganda Christian and Martyrs universities.


JJ Bola, is a Kinshasa born, London raised writer, poet, educator and workshop facilitator. London and UK based, but also international; Paris, Brussels, Boston etc, most recently San Francisco and Oakland, where he won the Oakland Poetry Slam. JJ performs regularly at shows and festivals such as  Tongue Fu, Vocals & Verses, Chill Pill, The Round House, Ventnor Fringe, etc as well as Universities; SOAS, UCL, Oxford, Lincoln, University of Birmingham, Standford University and Merrit College in the Bay and other public institutions.

JJ Bola has published two books of poetry Elevate and Daughter of the Sun (ebook). His third, and latest, is his most comprehensive poetry collection WORD, which was launched to a sold out crowd, during Refugee Week on the 18th of June 2015 at Dalston Roof Park.  JJ Bola’s work is centred on a narrative of empowerment, humanisation, healing of trauma as well as discovery of self through art, literature and poetry. Creating the increasingingly popular addage, 'hype your writers like you do you rappers', he believes that the true purpose of poetry (art) is to expose the reality of this world and how to, most importantly, survive it.


Patrick Vernon OBE is a leading expert on African and Caribbean genealogy in the UK. Founder of Every Generation Media and 100 Great Black Britons. Patrick was selected by the Queen as Pioneer of the Nation for Cultural History in 2003. He has researched family history and Swahili culture in East Africa and Oman as a Clore Fellow and has advised the BBC, The National Archives, The National Trust, Royal Geographic Society, Victoria & Albert Museum and the British Council. Patrick write for The Voice, Guardian, and Mental Health Today. In 2012 he was awarded an OBE for his work tackling health inequalities for ethnic minority communities in Britain. Having worked for the Department of Health, NHS and the voluntary sector Patrick is an Associate Fellow at the Department of the History of Medicine at Warwick University, England. Patrick is a Patron of Santé a refugee and asylum seekers social enterprise based  in Camden.


Sareeta Domingo is a writer and editor from South East London. Her debut novel The Nearness of You will be published by Piatkus Books in May 2016.

She has been commissioned to write several short stories in collections of erotic fiction for Agent Provocateur, and was also commissioned to write a novella in the genre for Pavilion Books. She writes reviews of contemporary romance titles on her blog, The Palate Cleanser.


Radhika Swarup spent a nomadic childhood in India, Italy, Qatar, Pakistan, Romania and England, which gave her a keen sense for the dispossessed. She has written opinion pieces for Indian broadsheets and the Huffington Post as well as short stories for publications including the Edinburgh Review. Her new novel, Where the River Parts, will be published by Sandstone Press in February 2016.


A graduate of the Royal College of Music International Opera School and the Flanders Opera School, Ghent, British baritone Peter Brathwaite is distinguishing himself as an exciting young operatic talent. Recent engagements have included role and company debuts with Opera de Lyon, the Nederlandse Reisopera, Opera Holland Park, Glyndebourne, English Touring Opera and Edinburgh International Festival. On the concert platform, he has performed with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, the Estonian National Symphony Orchestra, HET Gelders Orkest, HET Symfonieorkest, the London Philharmonic Orchestra and the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra. Brathwaite is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts.

“Virile baritone, clean enunciation and sensitive acting”(The Telegraph)

“The indefatigable young baritone lights up the stage every time he appears”(WhatsOnStage)


Courttia Newland is the author of seven works of fiction including his debut, The Scholar. His latest novel, The Gospel According to Cane, was published in 2013 and has been optioned by Cowboy Films. He was nominated for the Impac Dublin Literary Award and The Frank O’ Conner award, as well as numerous others. His short stories have appeared in many anthologies and broadcast on Radio 4. He is currently a PhD candidate in creative writing.


Catherine Johnson has written many novels for young readers including the award winning Sawbones, and her most recent, Carnegie Medal nominated The Curious Tale of the Lady Caraboo. She's spent a life in stories, working at Centerprise in Dalston, as writer in residence in Holloway Prison as well as working on acclaimed British film Bullet Boy. She's written for BBC1 - Holby City - as well as with Simon Schama on Rough Crossings. This year sees the sequel to Sawbones in October and some exciting TV developments. She is also a mentor with MegaphoneWrite.


Peter Kalu is a novelist, playwright and poet and has previously won the BBC Playwrights Award, The Voice/Jamaica Information Service Marcus Garvey Scholarship Award and Contact/BBC Dangerous Comedy Prize. His YA books include, The Silent Striker and Being Me.


Rachel Shabi has written extensively on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the Middle East. Her award-winning book, Not the Enemy: Israel's Jews from Arab Lands, was published in 2009. She received the International Media Awards Cutting Edge prize in 2013, the Anna Lindh Journalism Award for reporting across cultures in 2011, and was shortlisted for the Orwell Prize the same year.


Raymond Antrobus is a poet, performer and hearing aid user, born and bred in East London, Hackney. His poems have been published in magazines and literary journals such as The Rialto, Magma Poetry, Oxford Diaspora's Programme, British Council Literature, Shooter Literary Journal, The Missing Slate, Morning Star, Media Diversified and University Of Arkansas Press. Raymond has read and performed his poetry at festivals (Glastonbury, Latitude, Bestival etc) and universities (Oxford, Goldsmiths, Warwick etc. He has also read internationally (South Africa, Kenya, North America, Sweden, Italy, Germany, Switzerland etc)

Raymond is co-curator of popular London poetry events Chill Pill (Soho Theatre and The Albany) and Keats House Poets. Raymond’s work has appeared on BBC Radio 4, The Big Issue, The Guardian and at TedxEastEnd. Sky Arts and Ideas Tap listed Raymond in the top 20 promising young artists in the UK. His second collection  - Shapes & Disfigurements Of Raymond Antrobus - is published by Burning Eye Books. He is currently one of six poet Laureates for London.

Her book, Breadfruit, was also published in 2007. Her latest poetry collection is Pepper Seed, published by Peepal Tree Press in 2013. 
Zen Cho was born and raised in Malaysia. She is the author of Crawford Award-winning short story collection Spirits Abroad, and editor of anthology Cyberpunk: Malaysia,
 both published by Buku Fixi. She has also been nominated for the 
Campbell Award for Best New Writer and the Pushcart Prize, and 
honour-listed for the Carl Brandon Society Awards, for her short 
fiction. Her debut novel, Sorcerer to the Crown, is the first 
in a historical fantasy trilogy published by Ace/Roc Books (US) and Pan 
Macmillan (UK). She lives in London with her partner and practises law 
in her copious free time.
Sunny Singh, was born in Varanasi,
India, and brought up in various Indian cantonment towns, Islamabad, Pakistan
and New York City, USA. She studied at Brandeis University (USA), Jawaharlal
Nehru University (India), and University of Barcelona (Spain).
Her debut novel, Nani’s Book Of
Suicides, published in 2000, was described as a “first novel of rare scope
and power.” The Spanish translation of the novel won the inaugural Mar de
Letras prize in 2003. Her second book, a work of non-fiction titled Single In The City: The
Independent Woman’s Handbook (2001), was a first-of-its-kind exploration of
single women in contemporary India and described as “witty and insightful.” Her
second novel, With
Krishna’s Eyes (2006), has been commended for its “profound insight” and
described as “memorable”. Her latest novel, Hotel Arcadia, is published
by Quartet Books and available from bookshops and e-retailers across UK. Her
short stories have been published by prestigious international literary
journals including The Drawbridge and World Literature Today.
Her creative nonfiction and academic writing has been
published across the world in key journals and anthologies. She also writes for
newspapers and magazines, in Spanish and English, across the globe.


Tendai Huchu’s first novel, The Hairdresser of Harare, was released in 2010 to critical acclaim, and has been translated into German, French, Italian and Spanish. His short fiction in multiple genres and nonfiction have appeared in The Manchester Review, Ellery Queen’s Mystery Magazine, Gutter, Interzone, AfroSF, Wasafiri, Warscapes, The Africa Report and elsewhere. In 2013 he received a Hawthornden Fellowship and a Sacatar Fellowship. He was shortlisted for the 2014 Caine Prize. His new novel is The Maestro, The Magistrate & The Mathematician.

Leila Aboulela is a Sudanese-born writer whose work, written in English, has received critical acclaim and a high profile for its distinctive exploration of identity, migration and Islamic spirituality. Highlighting the challenges facing Muslims in Europe and “telling the stories of flawed complex characters who struggle to make choices using Muslim logic”, Aboulela’s work explores significant political issues. Her personal faith and the move in her mid-twenties from Sudan to Scotland are a major influence on her work. Literary influences include Arab authors Tayeb Salih and Naguib Mahfouz as well as Ahdaf Soueif, Jean Rhys, Anita Desai and Doris Lessing. The Scottish literary landscape and writers such as Alan Spence and Robin Jenkins have also been influential. Leila Aboulela’s works have been included in cultural educational programs supported by the British Council and the National Endowment for the Humanities in the US.
Robin Yassin-Kassab is the author of the novel The Road from Damascus. 
He
has lived and worked in London, France, Pakistan, Turkey, Syria, Morocco, Saudi
Arabia and Oman and now lives in Scotland.
He is co-author with Leila al-Shami of the forthcoming book on the Syrian revolution and war, Burning Country. He
has lived and worked in London, France, Pakistan, Turkey, Syria, Morocco, Saudi
Arabia and Oman and now lives in Scotland.

His
journalism on Syria has appeared at the Guardian, the National, al-Jazeera,
Foreign Policy and elsewhere.
He
is a co-editor and regular contributor to PULSE,
recently listed by Le Monde Diplomatique as one of its five favourite websites.

Selina Nwulu is a writer, poet and researcher for a think tank. She has written for a number of outlets such as The Guardian, Red Pepper, the Free Word Centre and Sable litmag. Her
 work has been published in a variety of magazines and anthologies 
including collections by the RSA, Lunar Poetry, and Emma Press. She has 
performed at a number of festivals including Glastonbury, Edinburgh 
Fringe and Fiery Tongues Festival in Holland. She has previously toured nationally with Apples and Snakes, representing London as part of the ‘Public Address II tour’
Her work often touches on social and environmental justice as well as identity, nostalgia and belonging.  
Her first chapbook collection, The Secrets I Let Slip, published by Burning Eye Books is out now. She is currently Young Poet Laureate for London 2015/6.




Jane Yeh is an American poet who has lived in England for over a decade. Born in New Jersey, she was educated at Harvard University, the University of Iowa—where she took an MFA at the prestigious writers’ program—and at Manchester Metropolitan University. She has taught at a number of universities in the UK, including Oxford Brookes University, and is now a Senior Researcher in Creative Writing at Kingston University. 
She has published two collections with Carcanet: Marabou (2005), which was nominated for the Forward Prize for Best First Collection, the Whitbread Book Award and the Jerwood Aldeburgh First Collection Prize, and The Ninjas (2012). She has received many other awards and fellowships for her work, including a New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowship, an Academy of American Poets Prize, and a residency at Yaddo, and was a judge for the 2013 National Poetry Competition. She has also written on a number of subjects, from fashion to sport, for publications including The Village Voice and The Times Literary Supplement.
London born author and speaker Tosin Coker is proclaimed as the UK’s first black sci-fi author.  Within less than three months of her powerful début 'The Mouth of Babes' hitting the bookshelves, Tosin had attracted the attention of esteemed producer and director, Menelik Shabazz.Calling upon her own life experiences as an inheritor of the Sickle Cell blood disorder, Tosin inspires by way of example, enthusing that "the only limitations are those set by the boundaries of the mind". 


Haris Durrani is a writer of fiction, memoir, and academic essays. His debut, Technologies of the Self, received the Driftless Novella Prize and is forthcoming from Brain Mill Press.  He is an M.Phil. candidate in History and Philosophy of Science at University of Cambridge and holds a B.S. in Applied Physics from Columbia University, where he co-founded The Muslim Protagonist Symposium. 
Anthony
Anaxagorou is an award winning poet, prose writer, playwright,
performer and educator. Since becoming the first young poet to win the London
Mayor’s Poetry Slam in 2002, he has continued to be an inspiring and important
voice in spoken word, publishing eight volumes of poetry, a spoken word EP and
a book of short stories. His collection ‘The Blink That Killed The Eye’ was
published by Jacaranda Books in 2014 and he has since won the Groucho Maverick
Award in 2015 consisting of a £10,000 prize, a lifetime membership to the club
and a Gavin Turk sculpture. Anthony is also the founder and artistic director
of Out-Spoken, an incredible event of poetry and live music in London, and he
is the chief editor and founder of Out-Spoken Press.
Anthony
has performed alongside artists such as Kate Tempest, Akala and Linton Kwesi
Johnson, as well as making numerous appearances on BBC, and in 2013 his poem
‘Dialectics’ was interpreted and performed by Cirque du Soleil in Las Vegas. Poems
such as ‘I Am Not A Poet’, ‘If I Told You’ and ‘You’ have achieved wide acclaim
for their honest and articulate interpretation of the truths of the world,
delivering powerful messages illustrated with wondrous imagery to create a
variety of meanings in a single line and a wealth of responses and reactions to
his emotion-evoking and awe-inspiring words.  




Bwesigye Bwa Mwesigire is the co-founder of the Writivism pan-African literary initiative. He has written about literature, arts, culture
and politics for a range of publications including The Guardian, This is Africa
and Chimurenga. He has appeared at a range of literary events including Africa
Writes, Storymoja, Ake and International Literature Showcase and is currently
an MSc Fellow at the African Leadership Centre (ALC), King's
College London. He has previously taught Law and Human Rights at Makerere,
Uganda Christian and Martyrs universities. 





JJ Bola, is a Kinshasa born, London raised
writer, poet, educator and workshop facilitator. London and UK based, but also
international; Paris, Brussels, Boston etc, most recently San Francisco and
Oakland, where he won the Oakland Poetry Slam. JJ performs regularly at shows
and festivals such as  Tongue Fu, Vocals & Verses, Chill Pill, The
Round House, Ventnor Fringe, etc as well as Universities; SOAS, UCL, Oxford,
Lincoln, University of Birmingham, Standford University and Merrit College in
the Bay and other public institutions. 
JJ Bola has published two books of poetry
Elevate and Daughter of the Sun (ebook). His third, and latest, is his most
comprehensive poetry collection WORD, which was launched to a sold out crowd,
during Refugee Week on the 18th of June 2015 at Dalston Roof Park.  JJ
Bola’s work is centred on a narrative of empowerment, humanisation, healing of
trauma as well as discovery of self through art, literature and poetry.
Creating the increasingingly popular addage, 'hype your writers like you do you
rappers', he believes that the true purpose of poetry (art) is to expose the
reality of this world and how to, most importantly, survive it.



Patrick Vernon OBE is a leading expert on African and Caribbean 
genealogy in the UK. Founder of Every Generation Media and 100 Great 
Black Britons. Patrick was selected by the Queen as Pioneer of the Nation
 for Cultural History in 2003.
 He has researched family history and Swahili culture in East Africa and
 Oman as a Clore Fellow and has advised the BBC, The National Archives, 
The National Trust, Royal Geographic Society, Victoria & Albert 
Museum and the British Council. Patrick write for
 The Voice, Guardian, and Mental Health Today. In 2012 he was awarded an
 OBE for his work tackling health inequalities for ethnic minority 
communities in Britain. Having worked for the Department of Health, NHS 
and the voluntary sector Patrick is an Associate
 Fellow at the Department of the History of Medicine at Warwick 
University, England. Patrick is a Patron of Santé a refugee and asylum 
seekers social enterprise based 
in Camden.





Sareeta
Domingo is a writer and editor from South East London. Her debut novel The Nearness of You will be published by
Piatkus Books in May 2016. 
She has been commissioned to write several short
stories in collections of erotic fiction for Agent Provocateur, and was also
commissioned to write a novella in the genre for Pavilion Books. She writes reviews of
contemporary romance titles on her blog, The Palate Cleanser.





Radhika Swarup spent a nomadic childhood in India, Italy,
Qatar, Pakistan, Romania and England, which gave her a keen sense for the
dispossessed. She has written opinion pieces for Indian broadsheets and the
Huffington Post as well as short stories for publications including the
Edinburgh Review. Her new novel, Where the River Parts, will be published by
Sandstone Press in February 2016. 

A graduate of the Royal College of Music
International Opera School and the Flanders Opera School, Ghent, British
baritone Peter Brathwaite is distinguishing himself as an exciting young
operatic talent. Recent engagements have included role and company debuts with
Opera de Lyon, the Nederlandse Reisopera, Opera Holland Park, Glyndebourne,
English Touring Opera and Edinburgh International Festival. On the concert
platform, he has performed with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, the Estonian National
Symphony Orchestra, HET Gelders Orkest, HET Symfonieorkest, the London
Philharmonic Orchestra and the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra.
Brathwaite is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts.
“Virile baritone,
clean enunciation and sensitive acting”(The Telegraph) 
“The indefatigable
young baritone lights up the stage every time he appears”(WhatsOnStage)



Courttia
 Newland is the author of seven works of fiction including his debut, 
The Scholar. His latest novel, The Gospel According to Cane, was 
published in 2013 and has been optioned by Cowboy Films. He was 
nominated for the Impac Dublin Literary Award and The Frank O’ Conner 
award, as well as numerous others. His short stories have appeared in 
many anthologies and broadcast on Radio 4. He is currently a PhD 
candidate in creative writing.



Catherine Johnson has written many novels
for young readers including the award winning Sawbones, and her most recent,
Carnegie Medal nominated The Curious Tale of the Lady Caraboo. She's spent a
life in stories, working at Centerprise in Dalston, as writer in residence in
Holloway Prison as well as working on acclaimed British film Bullet Boy. She's
written for BBC1 - Holby City - as well as with Simon Schama on Rough
Crossings. This year sees the sequel to Sawbones in October and some
exciting TV developments. She is also a mentor with MegaphoneWrite.


Peter Kalu is a novelist, playwright and
poet and has previously won the BBC Playwrights Award, The Voice/Jamaica
Information Service Marcus Garvey Scholarship Award and Contact/BBC Dangerous
Comedy Prize. His YA books include, The Silent Striker and Being
Me.



Rachel Shabi has written 
extensively on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the Middle East. Her
 award-winning book, Not the Enemy: Israel's Jews from Arab Lands, was 
published in 2009. She received the International Media Awards Cutting 
Edge prize in 2013, the Anna Lindh Journalism Award for reporting across
 cultures in 2011, and was shortlisted for the Orwell Prize the same 
year. 





Raymond Antrobus is a poet, performer and hearing aid
user, born and bred in East London, Hackney. His poems have been published
in magazines and literary journals such as The Rialto, Magma Poetry, Oxford
Diaspora's Programme, British Council Literature, Shooter Literary
Journal, The Missing Slate, Morning Star, Media Diversified and University Of
Arkansas Press. Raymond has read and
performed his poetry at festivals (Glastonbury, Latitude, Bestival etc) and
universities (Oxford, Goldsmiths, Warwick etc. He has also read internationally (South Africa, Kenya,
North America, Sweden, Italy, Germany, Switzerland etc)
Raymond is co-curator of popular London poetry events Chill Pill (Soho Theatre and The
Albany) and Keats House Poets.
Raymond’s work has appeared on BBC Radio 4, The Big Issue, The Guardian and at
TedxEastEnd. Sky Arts and Ideas Tap listed Raymond in the top 20 promising
young artists in the UK. His second
collection  - Shapes &
Disfigurements Of Raymond Antrobus - is published by
Burning Eye Books. He is currently one of six poet Laureates for London.

story:
Frederic Heffeler Hates the Moon

Hi, I'm Rob MacPhee, man-about-town, musician, author-hopeful. You may know me because you either like, hate, or feel indifferent about my band, Paper Lions. You also may know me for a host of other reasons. You may not know me at all.

Over the last several years, I have written a children's book, or as I like to call it, "a children's epic poetic anti-saga." My major goals were to write a book for children, make it something adults can enjoy, and avoid any stupid learning of dumb lessons; I believe I succeeded. 

Upon completion of the writing and editing process, I began to look for an appropriate illustrator. I had no luck until I met the excellent and talented Jeff Alward, whose work you can see at the top of the page. Jeff is in the midst of illustrating the book right now, and it should be finished within a few weeks. Contributions made to my campaign will go toward paying for the illustrations to be completed, as well as any fees that arise from publishing. 

I am only including one choice of perk, and the reason for this is simple. Without overwhelming demand, I won't be creating hard copies of the book. I am self-publishing digitally, and selling copies for $1.99, forever. Therefore, your $2 (or more, if the spirit moves you) contribution will net you one digital copy of the book. Feel free to purchase multiple copies for family, friends, enemies, etc.

Below, you will find an excerpt of the book (two of sixteen stanzas). If you like what you read, and want to help me publish it, please consider contributing to my campaign. If you like what you read, and want to help out in a non-financial way, please share my campaign through any social media outlet in which you are engaged. You will have my gratitude.

Thanks!

Rob


An Excerpt from Frederic Heffeler Hates the Moon


"I don't like the moon," Frederic Heffeler said,

To his mother who sat with a book and some bread.

"Is that so?" she replied, "and why is that, dear?"

"It sneaks through my window at night, bright and clear.

It keeps me awake 'til my thoughts become thick.

So I'm going to explode it with a dynamite stick."

"Oh my," said his mother, scooping jam with a spoon.

"And how do you plan to get up to the moon?


Your arms," she went on, "will never be wings."

"I'll fly on the back of the Great Dragon King,"

Frederic declared as he splayed out his arms,

Exhibiting incontrovertible charm.

"So I'll be in the shed, then I'm off 'til who knows?"

His mother looked up, "Take a change of warm clothes."

"I'm five," huffed Frederic, "I know how to dress."

"Home for supper?" asked Mother; the boy replied, "Yes."

story:
In its two years of existence, the Coachella Valley Independent has come a long way—and has done a lot to inform and enrich the lives of local residents.

However, we still have work to do in our effort to give the Coachella Valley the best alternative publication/news organization it’s ever had—and we’re asking for your help in expanding our coverage and strengthening our distribution.

As for distribution: We're currently in 365 or so locations across the region, from Desert Hot Springs, through Palm Springs, and all the way down to the Salton Sea; we’re even at Chiriaco Summit and in select locations in the Yucca Valley area. That’s pretty darned good—but we can do better. We want to boost that number of locations to around 400, and we want to do better at our existing locations. This effort will help us purchase new wire indoor racks, and will allow us to refurbish, repair and perhaps replace some of our outdoor distribution boxes.

The vast majority of the funds we hope to raise will help us improve what we do best—journalism. We want to increase our arts and events coverage, for example. Right now, we’re doing a fine job of covering band/club/popular music and reviewing multi-week theatrical performances; our visual arts coverage is also among the valley’s best. However, many events outside of these categories have tended to fall through the cracks, so we want to hire more writers on a freelance basis to patch these figurative cracks.

On the food and drink side: No publication in the valley does full, honest restaurant reviews—the kind in which restaurants are visited more than once by an unannounced reviewer who pays his or her own way. Next year, we hope to start doing at least two reviews per month.

Finally—and most importantly—we want to boost our news coverage. The Desert Sun and other traditional news sources are continuing to get hammered by layoffs and cutbacks—making our job more important than ever.

Thank you in advance for your help—be it in the form of a contribution, spreading the word about the campaign—or both.

—Jimmy Boegle, editor and publisher, Coachella Valley Independent

story:
Daniel & Cynthia Osuna


Por más de 10 años hemos servido a la juventud de la región. Nos apasionan los jóvenes y verlos llegar al propósito de Dios para sus vidas. Creemos que la manera en que viven su noviazgo puede contribuir o perjudicar enormemente a su plan de vida. 

Nuestro Libro ya esta terminado

Nuestro libro ya está terminado, fueron meses de arduo trabajo y revisiones para que quedara como un libro completo. Creemos que es el último libro de noviazgo que vas a necesitar.  Con tu ayuda lograremos publicarlo y distribuirlo.
El Impacto que Esperamos
Creemos que el libro Guía de noviazgo alternativo les dará poderosas herramientas para tomar buenas decisiones en cuanto a su relación de noviazgo rumbo al matrimonio. Es simplemente una perspectiva que rompe con el modelo comercial de noviazgo que ha resultado ser tan ineficiente. Nuestra esperanza es que este libro evite muchos corazones rotos y produzca muchos matrimonios sanos.

Otras formas de apoyarnos

  • Compartiendo nuestras redes sociales Facebook, Twitter e Instagram
  • compartir las publicaciones con mensajes para jóvenes!

¡Muchas gracias de antemano!
